tips.description: Hackers often target routers with factory settings. Use a strong and unique admin password to reduce the risk.
This ensures your Wi‑Fi traffic is protected from snooping or unauthorized access.
Making your network name invisible adds an extra layer of privacy from casual intruders.

tips.highlight: Keep your software up to date
tips.description: Regular updates patch vulnerabilities in your operating system and applications.
Real-time protection helps defend against malware, spyware, and ransomware.

tips.highlight: Use strong device passwords or biometrics
tips.description: Avoid easy-to-guess PINs. Use fingerprint or facial recognition where possible.

tips.highlight: Be cautious with email attachments and links
tips.description: Phishing attacks often come through emails pretending to be from legitimate companies.

tips.highlight: Use a VPN on public networks
tips.description: If working from home or traveling, a VPN encrypts your internet traffic and secures your data.
This adds a second layer of verification to your online accounts, even if your password is compromised.
